content:
6, 2015
												Wakfu is a turn based mmorpg with a cute anime-like style. The combat system is similar to final fantasy tactics and players are able to shape the the environment. But there are not a lot of quests that will tell you what to do and lead you the way, it's more of a sandbox game where you decide what to do and where to go.If you prefer quests from Lv. 1 to XXX this game will not appeal to you.Main Quests:When you create your character you will get your first quest chain until like Lv. 12-15.I think the next is around Lv. 35 to get your first mount.The next one is at Lv. 50Then there is another one around 90~100...As you can see, there is alot of spare time between those main quests. So, if you don't like to explore the world yourself, you will be stuck after each quest chain ends.Classes and SpellsThere are 16 classes to choose from, each once has its unique fighting style. These are no archetype classes you'd normally expect. Except like 3 classes which are similar to Warrior, Archer and Assassin. But you probably won't know which one is the warrior, if you see them, they are more like a mix of a Barbarian, a Warrior and an idiot (The game calls them stupid, not me I swear). There are also Faries, Bamboo-Milkoholics, Machosists, Robots, Human-Plants, Gambling Cats, old greedy Farts, Terrorists and a few more...But there is no higher class change at a higher level or something like that. You will be stronger when you level up your Class abilities and elemental spells.There are 4 Elements: Fire, Water, Earth, Air. All Spells in the game are categorized in one of them.Each class has access to 3 Elements, 5 spells for each Element.Each class also has 10 Class specific supportive abilities. 5 of them are active spells, the other 5 are passives.What are the elements for? Everything has Elemental Damage and Resistance. If you have a lot of Fire Damage, your fire spells will deal more damage, if the target you attack has a lot of fire resistance, you will deal less damage with your fire spells.Elemental damages can go over 100% to infinite. Elemental resistance has a maximum of 100%(which would block 100% damage of that element), but you cannot reach that. I have about 60% resistance at Lv. 105. So you can at least reach that :)For your first 20% resist in each element you will need 100 points in resist, which are 5 points for each % resist. After that it will slightly increase the amount needed for each % resist.LevelingThe best way to level up your character is probably by doing dungeon runs. You get a wisdom bonus in there, which increases exp gained. 20 Wisdom = 20% more exp after the fight. To enter a dungeon, you will need the corresponding key, which are usually not too hard to get. If you know what monsters are inside the dungeon, kill the same monsters outside of the dungeon, they will drop it sooner or later. You can also craft keys by using the items those monsters drop. Usually its 7x Item X.There are also daily quests in each zone of the world, which tells you bring 10 items of the monsters that are lurking around. If you collect 20, you don't need to hunt them tomorrow, just accept and finish the quest immediately. Those quests give you a decent amount of exp.I think in all zones except the first one in each nation are also timed events with a small variety of quests. There are either monsters appearing, or other random stuff you have to interact with before the time runs out. Those are highlighted in green if you see them while the event is ongoing. There is a new event every 10-15 minutes I think and the exp is also decent if it's around your level.There is a lot more to talk about this game but if I tried to explain every detail I know, I would need 2+ hours to write this review. I will try to end this with a short Pro and Con.PROS+ High Variety of Classes (16 Classes)+ 10+1 Crafting Professions (the extra profession can't be leveled. you can create in game money called Kama with it, if you have the materials)+ 6 Gathering Professions+ Battles get more challenging at later levels (monsters gain passives, you can't always ignore to win battles)+ You have your own home, which is a bag and is accesible from almost everywhere (You can put furnite in it, plant stuff and there is an item storage)+ A lot of costumes for customization. Also everything you wear, besides the belt, can be seen on your character, haven't seen that in many 2D games.+ If you don't have friends, you can have 2 Sidekicks fighting by your side.+ Shape the world, Kill monsters, replant them, cut trees and flowers and plant them where you want em, but be careful, in the open world everyone has access to this.CONS- Bugs, Glitches. The longer you play, the more you will find. Some are just minor bugs that don't matter much, others are killing you in battle. The worst battle bug I know is that you can't do anything for 1 round. I have that once in maybe 2 weeks. The friend I play with has it every 25-30 battles. I guess, it depends on your computer.- lack of guidelines- Most crafting professions don't feel satisfying to level (only a few things you can craft are better than hunting equip)- Some gathering professions are really slow and boring to level (Ex.: Trapper, most stuff you collect from monsters to level up will be thrown away to save item slots)I play and like this game because the combat is fun and challenging to me. In an even battle, every wrong step you take, might cost you or your party members life. The special effects are also pretty well done. If some bugs and glitches scare you away, you won't be playing for long. Give it a try if you like most of the things I have mentioned about Wakfu. If the bugs you find don't affect your gameplay experience too much, you will enjoy it.

content:
y 9, 2016
												short version:think final fantasy tactics mixed with a bit of harvest moon (or....augh....farmville.....we dont have long wait times though) and a dash of borderlands comedy into a sandbox MMORPG.long version:1.its a turn based MMORPG (all capitals btw,because they REALLY focus on that),there is a good community,and a ♥♥♥♥ ton of classes to choose from,and they're pretty non tradisional,except some ofc.2.while not as hard as fire emblem,you might need to think of a plan sometimes,like if placing a trap on the floor to finish off an enemy while reseulting to friendly fire (did i mention friendly fire is on?yeah,have fun trolling),3.No friends or no one to join to help you fight?No problem,they have a sidekick system (although i prefer to call them minions)basicly they're like those characters in turn based RPGs that you can control,they start at level 1 when you get them,so dont be surprised if they have less health,although some have skills unique to them,which can be advantage,you mostly need to get to the cash shop for them,which i hate doing,it is pretty nice of them to give you a free minion (cant help calling them that) after a quest and a trial one every now and then4.there is a ecosystem....system built into the game,you can replant and harvest some crops/trees and animals(?),if the ecosystem reaches a certain threshold,you get a bonus.5.professions,there are alot of professions you can chose,mind you professions are different from classes,classes are MOSTLY combat base,while profession is can become a side income or help you in combat by either making food for buffs,close range weapons,AoE weapons (yes there are AoE weapons) or armor,or just a plain hobby,and these professions arent limited to crafting weapons,food or armor,they can also become a handyman or lumberjack or hell,a fisherman,most professions can help each other,so having other poeple in different professions help.and all those stuff you can get into in a matter of hours,hell i havent joined a guild or faction/nationpros and conspros:1.free to play2.an ACTUAL turn based MMORPG thats good3.ecosystem4.professions5.nation (joining certain nations will make you their enemies,which is a nice lore effect)6.active community7.secrets within the game,like a portal giving you a cape somewhere in the beginner area (hint:its at the lower right corner of the map,also when you get it,read the description)cons:1.with everyone F2P...there are always microtransactions....although its not as bad as others,its still there,they do give you a free sidekick and a mount via quests and 5 character slots....im looking at you realm of the mad god2.its a birds eye view game,and when you start at the beginner town,its pretty hard to get a grasp of whats what and whos who,like if this chocobo thing does anything or this statue have any fuctional purpose,or maybe if this board will lead me to the market3.speaking of grasping,they dont really teach you what is what and where,hell i had a friend tell me the minimap pops out via shift+m,and best thing is they dont tell you how to use the market or what it looks like4.since you have a ecosystem to run,you need to watch what you kill and what you harvest,make sure to replant EVERYTHING you kill just to be safe5.you REALLY need to read stuff,like badly,if you dont,you might not learn what to do or get the humor of it,its not as bad as dark souls lore being hidden in item descriptions though6.when you finish the tutorial,you're probably gonna exited to chose your class,the thing what i hate about choosing classes IN GAME (you can probably wiki them for better description) is they're vague,you might THINK that feca's shield is a tank but nope,its a (ranged) buffer and trapperoverall it takes a little learning and adjusting to the game,and if you can do that,you'll start having fun,plus it is a free to play game with optional cash shopmy review:8/10give it a gotakes a few hours of adjusting to the game thoalso read item descriptions,you wont regret it

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 18, 2014
												TL;DR- Great Tactics/MMO game. You should give this amazing, under-rated game a shot. Wakfu is an amazing game that doesn't get enough credit. It has been (mostly) improved by the most resent major update. (9/9/2014) The art and animations in this game are beautiful, the music isn't bad, and the new revamped level up system makes the game much more accessible, and actually give you a feeling of progression over the old stat system. If you like Tactic games and MMOs I don't see how you would not enjoy this game. There are two free and effortless character respecs. The first is given at level 30, when you have all of the skills unlocked and plenty of time to try them all out, and another at 80, when you have a much better understanding of the game. Aside from the two respecs given you can do a quest to respec, or buy a respec from the cash shop, to save time.There are many classes to choose from, and they are all very different from each other. You have the more basic classes, such as the Iop, who is just a front line warroir. Then you have the much more complex classes like Xelor, whos spells have alternating effects every turn. On top of that each class can be played multiple ways. No matter what class you are looking for Wakfu will have a character for you. The new starter zone/quests are mostly enjoyable. The starter quests explain a bit more, and reward with more items that you weren't introduced to at all before, such as; Weapons/Armor, Haven Bag Decorations, Shop Stalls. Inventory Bags, and a Pet. HOWEVER. The quests themselves are ... not very fun. Its not that they are bad, or poorly done, but they do not fit into this game. A sliding block puzzle is great, but not in a turn based tactics game. The other quest that doesn't fit uses silly context to teach you the mechanics to a (boss?) fight that you have to do right after... It would have been much more enjoyable to just FIGHT something. There is a daily quest NPC on every map that is simply collect X from Y and bring them to me. Much less annoying. Although nothing original there, if you are fighting the monsters to level anyway, it is a welcome bonus to exp. I have not tried the new "Mercenary" quests, so I cant give a review on those. Dungeons are fun (I enjoy them at least) and there is no lack of them. The new token system means you wont run a dungeon 20 times and still not get the drop you were looking for. On top of this, any item from the token machines is account bound, so you can't flood the market with items you got from boss tokens. At the start of the game Dungeons and boss fights are simple and straightforward, the further you get into the game the more challenging and complex dungeons become. PVP has had more content added in the recent update, bringing PVP gear and rewards. Much more active PVP with the nation vs nation, and limited alliances between nations. If you do not have PVP turned on the only way someone can attack you is through the PK system, witch was already in the game. The level range to attack other players with PVP turned on is much too high right now, at 50 levels apart. I have high hopes that they will lower this range to 20, at the most. I believe for that to happen we would have to see a population increase. The Ecosystem ... system, is both fun, and frustrating. On any given map there are values of monsters and resources that should be on the map, within your nations you gain points by putting said resources within these ranges. While the ecosystem is in balance, you will also enjoy a buff on that map. The Riktus clan gains bonuses by destroying this balance, so this also fuels PVP. The frustrating aspect of this is that little to no players seem to care about the ecosystems, the problem with that is that monster populations are a part of these. I have gone to maps with monsters nearly extinct because no one is repopulating them. An easy process through gathering from said monsters, and simply using the gathered material on an empty cell on the map. I believe the reason behind this is no one really want to level the professions used to manage these things. As much as I would love to see a population increase I fear it will bring mass extinctions to the beginning areas of the game, so please, at least repopulate the monsters.

ber 18, 2014
												Alright before anyone complains about my time, I played this during its closed beta period and I have the costume and title to prove that.Now:wakfu is pretty interesting for a mmo as it takes turn based strategy to the next level by making you have to think ahead to compete with others.For Example: I play a xelor, which is one of the least player friendly classes you can play. To use this class properly you have to understand how to use the dial ability that comes with the race/class. Proper use of it will lead to either your victory or imminent downfall.Now for those of you who are free to play gamers: Fair warning, I'm not sure if this game still uses its membership policy or not for minting kamas and using your factions land. So if it does, you are only really going to be able to affect the eco-system of the starter region, everywhere else you will need membership to modify. If it does not do that anymore than thank god and good riddens. Now go out there and train your skills..... And thats all I got for this review...

content:
r 9, 2014
												Only played for 7 hours, and didn't get far in the game. Just one character at lvl 14.I liked this game and still plan on playing it. It's pretty fun, and I don't even like anime MMOs to be honest. The choices and strategy is what caught my eye, and it's easy. So that's a bonus.Kind of annoying that you absolutely need to do the tutorial every single time you make a new character, because if you don't, you do not get skill points and the level you were in the tutorial map. If you decide to skip the tutorial, it puts you into the online world with no skill points to spend, and you're level 1, and all the "low level" creatures are level 5 or higher.So skipping the tutorial is an absolutely stupid idea, and a waste of time. Because it traps you in the house and will not let you leave. So you have to delete that character and do the tutorial. It shouldn't let you skip it if it just traps you inside of a house and never lets you decide if you want to go back and do the tutorial or actually leave the house. You're just stuck there until you decide to redo everything. Which is the most pointless option they give you. Long story short, DON'T SKIP THE TUTORIAL. It's an absolute waste of time and your character will be useless afterwards.Also the compass sometimes does not track my missions. It will for a short time, then it vanishes without explination. I'm talking about the above ground quests, not the quests underground. It get's really irritating having to keep pulling up the stupid quest thing and  click the compass "Follow" button every single time. I'm still trying to figure out how I sell my garbage items to get money. Where is the NPC that just buys all your crap items? Or do I have to drop everything on the ground. Some things aren't explained in the game, and you have to figure it out for yourself most of the time.

Wasted on grind, of course.

ber 28, 2014
												You've already played this game twice. The first time was when the game was still under Squarenix's publication (They later relinquished it due to Ankama's lack of management). You left it once the game left beta and it created one mistake after the next. The second was when everyone flocked to the SEA servers which were free to play, unlike the American one's monthly fee for a laggy java game. You quit a second time after you calculated it would take you months of clicking on rocks to get your mining level to where you want it to be.Now you want to try it again. Oh, maybe it will be better. Maybe it will be more fun. While you're betting on that, Ankama is betting on you falling into the same trap for the third time. Just go watch the anime if you want your French hips so badly.

												A fun MMO that has a different playstyle than any other MMOs I have played. Turn based, although it is quite grindy. Crafting is useful though be prepared to also grind for materials, and have professions require mats from different professions. There is government and PvP for those that like that.Interesting storyline and there are quests to be had. I've played since its beta and it has come a long way, mostly for the better I feel. Cash shop has mostly cosmetic purchases, and while free to play there are benefits for being a subscriber/premium member. A nice time sink for those MMO fans out there that want a different feel to the usual.

content:
ry 2, 2015
												A very beautiful and unique take on MMOs. The strategic turn based combat is very well done, the monsters, skills and spells look good and its a world I keep going back to. Like any MMO, it will take you some time to level, but the game gives you a companion that makes levelling a lot quicker than it otherwise would be. Im more than happy with the pace of levelling and you get a level every couple minutes if you are in level appropriate areas.The only thing that frustrates me is that the game has recently been updated to be a lot better and more friendly to players, but the player wikis have not been updated to reflect this. Mob levels have changed, some locations have been moved about, and I have found myself directed to places that no longer have the item i require once or twice. But the exploration aspect is a very big plus.Overall, an amazing game. Like it so far (180+ hours as I write this) and will udpate if my feelings change

If you do not have PVP turned on the only way someone can attack you is through the PK system, witch was already in the game. The level range to attack other players with PVP turned on is much too high right now, at 50 levels apart. I have high hopes that they will lower this range to 20, at the most. I believe for that to happen we would have to see a population increase. The Ecosystem ... system, is both fun, and frustrating. On any given map there are values of monsters and resources that should be on the map, within your nations you gain points by putting said resources within these ranges. While the ecosystem is in balance, you will also enjoy a buff on that map. The Riktus clan gains bonuses by destroying this balance, so this also fuels PVP. The frustrating aspect of this is that little to no players seem to care about the ecosystems, the problem with that is that monster populations are a part of these. I have gone to maps with monsters nearly extinct because no one is repopulating them. An easy process through gathering from said monsters, and simply using the gathered material on an empty cell on the map. I believe the reason behind this is no one really want to level the professions used to manage these things. As much as I would love to see a population increase I fear it will bring mass extinctions to the beginning areas of the game, so please, at least repopulate the monsters.

												Sure, the hours I've put in for Wakfu on Steam so far have been measly, but I've been playing Ankama's games ever since Dofus came out back in 2005. number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
15, 2015
Short version: Wakfu is a game I would like to enjoy. The art style is unique and well made turn-based combat is a rare thing to find in any MMO. But there are some glaring issues that can keep you from enjoying the game. Grind being the biggest one.With a good group, however, the game is much more enjoyable. Try to lure in a few of your friends.Good sides:+ Art style is beautiful,+ Combat is, at it's best, very challenging,+ Unique and interesting world with economy ran purely by players.Bad sides:- There is barely any info for new players on what to do. You can call this a sandbox game, but you should definitely explain at least the basics. I was 13 hours into the game and still clueless on so many things,- The Grind. In action filled MMOs I can accept this and even enjoy it, up to a point. But in a turn-based game it becomes so mind-numbingly boring to constantly repeat the same process over and over. Quests are as grindy as they get,- Party tools. Ways to easily find and party up with other players are missing or at least I wasn't informed of any during the first 13 hours. This is a pity as the most challenging fights could be very interesting due to the variety on comboes and tactics available.Overall I can't recommend this unless you happen to have a group of friends to actively play with. Taking on considerably higher level enemies and coming out on top is a great feeling and the fights can be real brain-teasers sometimes. But the game's just too obscure and the progress too slow for those few instances to be worth it.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
er 4, 2016
												WAKFU is an interesting type of mmo, a grid based stratagy rpg. It's easily one of the top games of its genre and should be looked at. Just making a North America/ Canada server, from just the French server, the game its opening up.  Using the manga/anime tv series WAKFU, you embark on the story line journey of the World of 12 to climb and defeat Ogrest (an ogre) who pretty much messed up the world and is on this Mount Zinit. Now like most RPG games you choose a class. Here there are 15 (?) very diffrent style, culture, playing styles for the game. Foggernaut, Cra, Scram, Xelor, Huppermage, Elcaflip, Eniripsa, Sacrier, Elitrope, Rogue, Feca, Enutruf, Pandawa, Masqueraider, Sadida, Iop and Osamodas. Now the names are crazy, but everyone brings something new and diffrent to the table. Each class has specific elemental abilities witch is the base of the game. ELEMENTS. Bad guys have strength and weaknesses to the elements and so do you. Each area and boss and creatures all changes by the elements and what is happening in the game....So keep on ur toes. You and can change the elemental happenings by doing certain things in the ecosystem to help, or take advantage of, or find that the one boss will eat you cause fire does nothing to him at this moment. You can even change baddies to extinct or help them out along with your gathering items. Controlling the ecosystem and elements. Thats alot of power... Along with a class you take on a nation to help you politic, merchant, protect and help along against the Ogrest bad guy. Brakmar, Sufokia, Bonta and Amakna. Politics is very real with the economy and both are in according to your nation. Perks for your nation add to your crafting skills. Crafting in this game you can take them all. No choosing. Take on gathering skills to obtain items to craft, to up craftingskills . Its the usual RPG gameplay here, but its ALL available to you. There is mining, lumberjack, farming, tamming for cooking, armorsmith, close and distance weaponary, handyman, and just all sorts to do. Use these gathering skills and crafting to make your character better while you follow the story line through the World of 12. NOW, the aspect of the game is that it is grid, turn based, stratagy combat. No mobs or running to and frow baddies. You click, challange a group and go into tactical combat. You lose- you go back to a Pheonix save point. ( its not that bad)  Win and gain loot equipment and exp. ALL THE RPG GOODNESS. Equipment, level elemental spells and characteristics to be the best. The usual. Combat can be casual to slow to OMFG, I made a wrong move and the boss destroys you and your group. Remember it is turn based and planning and thinking is required...It's not a faceroll keyboard or click shoot till you hit the baddies.YES ! groups are made and incrouraged in this game like most MMO's. You also can have a sidekick to help you out. Sidekicks are leveld and geard by you and are earned through quests, missions, acheivments and such. Everyone starts off with the Astrub Knight. Hes a neat soldier, with a lance and melee, chopchops for you. Pets and mounts are also in game for fun and helping.  Custamize and collect pets, mounts and sidekicks to your liking or play style.So what class will you make? will you get to the top of Mount Zinit? and master your characters abilities for grid based stratagy combat!. It does have humor, the story line is pleasing with good music and voice acting. Its more fun then chess and checkers and its casual . The graphics and baddies can be a bit on the kid side, due to it being a kids ''cartoon''. The first dugeon bosses are a Cat, Larva, Chicken and Sheep. So yeah no ghoulies or anything to make your kids wimper. Also there is a problem that steam acheivments have not and seem not to be fixed yet for the game and the game of as now, is kinda low in number and population. BUMMER.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
y 28, 2016
												Definitely one of, if not THE best MMO I've ever played. Other than amazing graphics, rather catchy soundtrack and a real user-friendly community, the list of faults is pretty small.Pros- .Flexible combat design. Lots of options to change strategy without losing the feeling of a fast-paced           challenge          .A friendly community that is fairly easy to emmerse yourself in and almost stress-free when looking for guilds to            join which is also encouraged since guilds provide helpful allies and stat bonuses.          .Not the average Pay-To-Play game. Subscribing does give you an upperhand to make you near invincible.          .And the class are extremely even, making the duels come down to skill and smart builds.          .The item crafting system gives an even larger feel to the gameplay, broadening the options further.Cons: .Like in most online games, it's got the fair share of trolls and ne'er-do-wells. Usually in the form of player killers            or simply disrupting the ecosystem.            .When new to the game, walking around to find dragoturkeys takes up a large portion of your time. The spacing             between each dragoturkey, depending where you are, makes it especially tedious should you forget to             'remember' one. However, this is do-able thanks to lush, vivid scenery and overall whimsy.           .A good amount of loot or quest rewards could be tagged as 'linked', making it impossible to trash. This could be             a mild irritation due to the fact that enough of these items could take up useful inventory space. A good way            to bypass this is to click the trashcan icon manually on each item instead of the click and drag.              Though I found, sometimes, this does not work.           .Your character's journey is NOT narrated by Morgan Freeman. Other than that, it really is a great game all around. The tutorial is HIGHLY reccomended for people new to class-buildingand strategy games. Each Spell, Passive, Stat and combat mechanics can seem a bit overwhelming at first, despite the childish look to it. I say, it's free, try it out.

content:
r 4, 2014
												The interface doesn't scale with higher resolutions, meaning it's way too tiny. Doesn't really matter though, cause it doesn't do much to inform you of anything. In other MMOs, the lack of information wouldn't be a problem. However, Wakfu includes quite a few puzzles and tasks that have nothing to do with the combat (and that every class must attempt). Most of the time reason saw me through the puzzles, while other times I found myself performing a task over and over, trying to figure out the exact order of things to accomplish. It was annoying and frustrating, considering the main draw for me is the combat.The combat is highly tactical, yet poorly explained. By the time you start to figure things out you will've already committed your character to a path you may not like. Several abilities are only usable on party members, but not all the abilities make it clear how they should be used. Worse still, the balance in several areas is extremely odd and non-conducive to experimentation unless you are in a group. This is not an MMO you can really play in single player, and that for me is a deal breaker. With so many good free to play games available, in addition to the good multiplayer games always going on sale, I can't recommend Wakfu unless you have lots of free time and like the style.

content:
ber 27, 2014
												So let's get this out of the way...it is not perfect.  I am not going to preach that it is the best thing since sliced bread but I am not going to say it is absolute ♥♥♥♥.  This game was made with children in mind and some of the visuals and names suggest the same.  This game was also a game you had to pay to play but as you can see it has gone free to play.  However, I do from time to time find some really funny, slightly immature jokes, that actually make me pause and laugh.  The infamous section in one of the regions named Mourning Wood is a big example of this.  There is even references to pop culture such as TMNT and it pokes fun at that series and the series of MMORPG's in general in some points.  However, some references are actually quite infuriating with their difficulty.  This can be solved with grabbing a friend or guild mate and running dungeons.  If that doesn't help you can always take up one of the environment quests that happens every so often that spawns in either special enemies or special objects into the world for a time and if you finish the quest, you get a decent reward of experience so it is not completely pointless.  They make the world feel very alive with the mobs interacting with each other and carrying out their daily routines.  There is also a special form of housing in this game called Havens.  You get a Haven Bag after the tutorial which is your portable house.  You can craft decorations to decorate or sell your useless ♥♥♥♥ to the unfortunate if you have a Display case to store them on.  There are also large zones for your guilds called Haven Worlds which contain buildings and houses.  I do not know much about this due to my guild being only level one.  But you can do Guild Quests which are 3 random assignments assigned every so often to earn guild points to help your guild level.  In addition to these quests, you can fight other guilds and other nations (Nations are basically a form of Alliance vs. Horde style and there are alliances and stuff and blah blah blah.) and earn guild points for every person in attendance of the battle.  Dungeons require keys that you can either farm off of the surrounding mobs, buying them from others or marketplace, or by crafting it if you have the materials and the proper training.  Dungeons are far from a cake walk and most definetly require at least one other person to help you.  But if you don't have anyone to play with, don't worry, you can unlock side kicks which are your companions that you control which come with their own abilities and can help you win the battles.  It plays similar to Final Fantasy Tactics.  As you use them, they grow more and more powerful.  So do your elemental abilities.  Of the probably 16 or so races, all can use magic, just some use it better than others, and there are specific spells just for your race.  You can have ordinary weapons, though these do not scale in damage and efficiency as you use it, so magic is a prefered option for heavy hitting.  Harvesting even has special encounters to mix it up, if you win, you gain 10x the resource you were collecting but if you fail, it halves your productivity with harvesting anything for an hour and it stacks higher and higher until you beat him, when you win, the buff and all the stacks are gone.  Good balancing.  This game is very strategy focused and if you get surrounded with no assistance, you are doomed.  Character customization needs some work but it is still great with some of the choices they give.  Combat is fun, dialog is interesting, and the social aspect is there.  There is no advertisers and everyone is friendly for the most part.  I recommend this game highly to all who love a challenging turn based strategy RPG.

content:
27, 2015
												Now that Steam has fixed its issues with Achievements, I'm enjoying seeing what I didn't realise I never knew about Wakfu. I started with Dofus, and gradually made my transition to Steam where I discovered more resources and a larger fanbase of my favourite games.Wakfu, like its predecessor, is a player-controlled environment where the ecology and economy of the world are entirely dependent on the users. While that seems simple enough, the game goes slightly further, allowing players to be elected as the governing rulers of an entire area of the map, dictating how money should be spent, and how the environment should thrive. The downfall to the above is that 100% of your item profits are from users. There are no NPCs to whom you can sell or trade items from your inventory.With a large collection of classes, Wakfu (and Dofus) has ensured the general availability of most preferred character archetypes, and has done extensive work keeping all the classes fairly well balanced. The tutorial is only generally comprehensive, so it's strongly suggested that trying a new class is done in the Incarnum world where everything is easy enough to not concern oneself with the dangers of durress. I personally prefer playing support roles, and have found that the highly acclaimed Eniripsa is fun, but the Eca and Xelor make healing very different, and definitely a lot more worthwhile in the aspect of overcoming challenges.Leveling is tedious, and the quests aren't very well thought out, so once you're finished with Astrub, prepare to grind. The maximum level takes a while to reach, especially since it's primarily done by grinding the entire way after LV20. Max level is 170 at the time of this writing, so there's a bit of perspective. The dungeons are awesome! when you can get friends to tag along, especially if you're following the difficult to locate storyline. I've read the manga and watched the anime, so seeing the dungeons and being part of the story is definitely a great deal of entertainment for me.If you're having a tough time getting through an area or quest, and haven't made friends on your server yet, no problem; Sidekicks are available in the market for Ogrin. If you're from Dofus, you know Ogrin can be purchased with Kama (in-game money), and thus is possible to acquire at no cost (for those who prefer not to pay). As a long-time subscriber, I highly recommend you give Steam's monthly options a try. I'm used to getting a pet or piece of gear with my Ogrine each month, but Steam goes a step further including more items that are only available through the now gaming giant.My final, most important factor to playing Wakfu is this: It's adorable! I love cute, and Ankama has done a great job at giving exactly that to me. Have fun, everyone, and feel free to join me on Nox or Remington. Just let me know you're coming.

content:
r 20, 2014
												This game is great!I played this game in the early beta before it went p2p and quit a long time after that. I started playing again when it wend f2p and now I use steam to play it. The game is much like it's predecessor Dofus. A turn based tactical mmo. But unlike Dofus you can change the world around U in real-time. Kill a lot of monsters and they get extinct cut down a lot of trees and there gone. And you can of course plant trees to let them regrow and you can even plant monsters so they come back.There is a lot of crafting in this game and you can do them all! I advise you to at-least take up backing and farming because bread is the most used way of healing after a fight. You can wait to heal, and that's OK when you are low lvl. But after a while when you get to a point where you have a lot of HP it will take to long to just wait to heal. There is a recent revamp of the game that changed the lvling up system. I think it did this in a good way and allows for more unique builds. They also did a revamp on the in game sets. You used to get a bonus from having a X amount of set items. These bonuses are now on the items themselves and the dmg type a set have is now randomly generated. I understand why they did this. So you can have any item you want and not be forced to use a complete set just to get that +1AP. But I Prefer the old system. That update has broken the economy a bit to. Items sell for a lot less now and its a lot harder to earn a decent amount of in game currency (kamas). But I hope that this is just now and will recover in a while. I think its best to join a active guild because this game really has a nice community. And its best to play with others. Best thing about the turn based system is that you have time to chat in fights with your team and discuses tactics our just have a good chat.  All in all its a great game and recommend it to everyone to try. It has a nice player-base, looks great, easy to run on almost any machine and although you can go P2P and never feels you have to, F2P gives you just as much to do in the game.

content:
2016
												Wakfu is a turn based MMORPG with a crafting system, political system and ecological system. There are multiple classes to choose from, all unique, no archetypes are used, and combat is interesting, if not engaging. Party members can make or break certain dungeons and the learning curve is certainly high, but once you hit your stride, the game opens up tremendously. There are also several gathering and professions you can learn/master all of which can factor in your early game. All the content is well thought of until you hit level 120-120 and then it all becomes irrelevant. The game has no endgame goals, PVP is pointless, token and nonexistent. The "government system" doesn't actually impact your game in any way and ecological features do not factor in the endgame content. Wakfu is a semi-meaningful 70 hours followed by nothing. If you like spending time by yourself crafting, farming and turn based combat, I recommend either getting Xcom2, Stardew Valley or Rune Factory on DS. Now, let me get to the bad stuff. The cash shop does not work. READ: Does not work. It isn't 100% reliable, which is pretty pathetic as far as F2P games go. Payment options are extremely limited cash shop or otherwise and there doesn't seem to be any change in the system. If you're looking for a more robust MMO experience, hit up Terra online, Tree of Savior, or even Ragnarok. Let this game die in peace.

r 16, 2014
												It was a great mmo with partial skill based leveling, full player generated economic system (the only way money appear in a game is being crafted by players), simulated ecosystem (climate, monsters and resourced depend on players behavior) and friendly adventure atmosphere, little buggy and class imbalanced, but tottaly playable.So it was two years ago. Steam says it was released  18 sep, 2014, which is not quiete true. According to wikipedia it was released 29 feb, 2012. Now servers populations is low on all the shards, and almost every start location is empty. The thing is, this game is not supposed to play in an empty world. So Steam is kinda tricky saying it had just released.But it's free and enjoyable without donate on low levels, so you should check it.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 13, 2016
												If you like turn based games, you might like this one too. For me honestly it was an acquired taste, cause I felt that the combat was boring at the start, and the missions too. So at the start of the game, I was already discouraged from playing more, but then I decided to play a bit more, to actually get somewhere in the game, I put a little more effort in and then some more and more, and gradually I felt that the game was becoming pretty fun. I have a level 25-ish character now, there are tons of dungeons, some quests here and there, and a craft system that DOES NOT limit you to only 2 ♥♥♥♥ing proffessions(as many as you want to have, instead). I also really love the idea that the entire ecosystem is the entire playerbases responsibility. They do a pretty decent job keeping it all going. If they decide, "I HATE THESE GOBBALS!!!" They can decide to kill all of them and extinct the species. There are 4 nations and they all have their own set of laws, and they are either enemies or allies of each-other. The laws are pretty cool, cause  if the governor chooses to  declare an endanged species as "ILLEGAL TO INTERACT WITH", you can disobey them and become a criminal to your own nation lmao.There's alot to this game and it is fairly unique, give it a go, and put a little bit more effort in too, this is a slower paced game.7/10  Awesome community, unique game

17, 2015
												Keep trying to fall in love with this game.Light TBS is so my style. Nothing too heavy unless youre really looking to kick ♥♥♥Its a grid based affair with elemental attacks, positioning, leveling abilities and a diverse class syste that encourages messing around. There's mecahnisms to respec for free and starting a new journey is always fun as each class has its own fighting style on the grid.Mechanics lend themselves towards the application and development of your own skills, little quests and a vibrant crafting economy.The choice in armour and gear is broad enough, and being part of a Guild can put you into a living community.Unless you choose your class to be money printer, where what you do is literally cause inflation. YOUR WHOLE JOB IS TO PRINT MORE MONEY, WHICH INCREASES THE AMOUNT OF MONEY IN A CLOSED SYSTEM. THE ECONOMY IS ♥♥♥♥ED UP. THE SYSTEM CRASHES IF NOT ENOUGH PEOPLE ARE PRINTING MONEY AND CRASHES AGAIN IF TOO MANY PEOPLE ARE, AS THE ONLY WAY TO DELETE MONEY IS TO HAVE IT POURED INTO A GUILD BASE FOT ITS UPGRADES.Also everything is adorable. Super adorable. So yeah. A Turn BAsed MMO with a lot of choice and quite a few little adventures to be had as you refine your strategies and travel with new freinds to kick ♥♥♥ and collect loot.

content:
ry 11, 2016
												NOTE: Steam DLC for this game doesn't go towards cards/boosters at all.That being said, you'll get more bang for your buck if there's a sale on them if you're a core player.In game shop isn't availble in tutorial.+ point for making it super easy to log in with steam- point for the gamer sin of locking a hero behind a paywall. A very high paywall.- steam sales =/= in game store sales on top of which there are sales on stuff in store. If you run the same game, why can't you package the steam bundles INTO your in game store the same as having sales on steam? Advertising trading cards that buying FROM the steam store don't go towards smack of free publicity without the payoff. In fact, a simple search on google reveals you tinkered with the in game/out game currency price to cash in on the new market on steam. The older players, who now can link into steam and may be interested in the card feature, won't exactly like the sales and booster unlock being on two seperate paths. In fact, it's almost a slap in the face of anyone interested in your trading cards, as you're effectively saying: "buy stuff on sale and unlock all this in game optional frill bonus content, or unlock the booster pack for the cards and just buy some exp boosters, which is almost begged for by rhe see through costume, 2,500 in game currency I might add, that just lets you stay the same way you looked without your silly bunny hat equipment...I'm happy you can pay to make some armor sets look like others just with the same stats as the other one, but I've never quite heard of a game that charges you to look naked, it's neat, I'll get it that, but for the price????????????!??????????????The paywalled character isn't game breaking; the in game shop is lacking in my opinion, except the boosts/subscription(exp boost/item drop/curency boost)/sidekicks, the costumes are kinda...limited. In spite of the franchise, the low costume count and their contents are just asian mmo style lazy, with the only one that really glows being a spikey samurai affair that we're all so familiar with, and hell, it only comes in one color mix of blue/teal/black. *I'm just getting into the series so this may be wrong *trying to avoid all this I simply bought a farmer costume, but my only options were pirate/drag queen as the rest is clearly geared towards ladies, muskateer, golden helmet = justice league/superhero (eh), dastardly black caped guy, mohawk S&M and that was about it. Whereas the female costumes had more variety and unless you count the super saiyan zodiac glow gear, generally better but not by much.All of which is really kinda spendy. I can only hope the money goes towards animation costs as well as server maintainence, because aside from sale prices on steam, I can't see someone except a die hard fan of doofus/wakfu or the cartoon wanting to spend these high prices, except for the exp boosts, to reward the creators and devs, and good for them, but it really feels more like a friendly mugging then a reward.28$ will get you 13,000 in game shop currency.3x30 exp days (90), which start the second you buy them, costs 8,100 in game shop currency.As far as sub prices go, especially an optional one, that's pretty good, but with every other item ranging 2000-3500 in game shop currency, to emotes, of all things, costing 900(effectively 2.5 dollars a pop) in game currency and there's about 15+ of them. Yeah, but at least unlike the sub it stays with you and that should make up for it, riiiiiiight? Ouch. Not for me, but for whoever is out there looking to unlock every little social thing in this game, it'll cost you. ...at least they animate nice, but maybe they should have been made into upgrades or version 2's of already available free emotes.Simply put: who is the target demographic you're trying to sell to? These prices seem wonky.The exp rate isn't an issue unless you can't stand a grind, especially knowing you can put money on it to speed it up. Depending on how you approach mmorpgs, this would be a deal breaker as for some, that would mean they're holding the xp hostage and the grind is even more arbitrary.That being said, have been meaning to catch up with this game and I'm glad I played it.

ry 26, 2015
												Wakfu.  What to say about this game?  Tactical combat?  Check.  Cute, anime inspired graphics?  Check.  15 unique classes?  Check.  Awesome art style?  Check.  Dungeons?  Check.  The list goes on and on.This game has personality by the boat load.  It was originally released in 2012 after a Closed Beta phase.  It is the successor to DOFUS, Ankama's other successful tactical RPG.  The games are different though.  I've never played DOFUS, but I know they're different.  If you like games like FF Tactics, then give this one a try!

content:
r 23, 2015
 I want to start out by saying, that if you can look past the initially grindyness of all MMORPG games, this game has a great community that you can return back to whenever. It's got great art, and wonderful music, cheezy PG-13 humor, and a great combat system. Possibly my favorite things about this game are the fact that the four nations of the game are entirely player-run. Economy, Ecology, etc. I play as a character that makes sure other players have enemies to fight and I try to keep a good ecological balance in the places I go. New players don't seem to realize that you can actually make an enemy type go extinct, so you have to be careful. This game gets an 8.5 or a 9 out of 10 from me. Anyways, that's it for my little introductory, brief review.  Full review; - Wakfu has an anime art style. This is because it's based around an anime of the same name, which is a french anime that, while I've personally never watched it, I do know plenty of the characters from it and I do know that it is a really rather nice anime, at least, from what I've heard from my friends. It has a great soundtrack also reminescent of the anime, and the humor is right around the same. The character designs for the game are all very solid, and even though it looks more reminescent of, say, a flashgame, where you can notice like, how the limbs move, maybe stretch, you'll notice that here, but it's in a cartoony sense so you won't pay it much mind, Id think. - Wakfu has a very robust crafting and harvesting economy. All your resources, except for ores, are things you either have to hand-plant, or harvest from groves or gardens that are maintained by other players. Nations can impose limits to how many plants can be harvested or planted in a percentile range, and going over or below those percentiles will actually impose a penalty on you, being something as low as a 'citizen-level' penalty, to something as strict as a kill-on-sight bounty. The monster ecology for this game is exactly the same as the herb/tree/plant ecology, and everything is controlled by the players, even influencing the weather in the game for certain regions, making one region better for certain plants, and even time of years will influence the temperature! - Wakfu's combat system is probably just as robust as it's ecological and economical parts, and I'll echo the sentiment that this game's combat system is similar to Final Fantasty: Tactic's. I can't really say too much about the current state of the combat system, as it's apparently undergone a good deal of revisions, according to my friends, and skills and passives no longer work like they used to, and work in different ways, but the combat system is still very in depth, and you can view all of it's workings, majorly, in your own character screen, so it may be intimidating at first, but the more you play around with it the more you get used to it. I'm not a very serious combative player so I can't fully explain how the combat system works, but there are a lot of classes for you to try out and tinker with, so there's probably at least one playstyle for you to like!- On Wakfu's community.. I'm going to make one thing clear; Every game will have it's people who are there to ♥♥♥♥ with other players. This game is no different, and there's no exceptions. Players from hostile nations can invade your nation and try and instigate you to attack them, or deforest your region you're in. They can also try and bring your nation's enemy population down, but that's majorly it, people can be ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s, but a major group of people are either rather kind and helpful or they keep to themselves, which is understandable. This game shines in my opinion for how it's all player run, and you, yes, you could be nominated for helping whichever country you join, or even ruling it, if you make enough friends and prove yourself to be worth of such a responsibility. It's daunting at first, but you'll meet plenty of people who've played as leaders or as parts of nations. It's like, a half-sort of roleplaying thing, half nation management for your role. I've never been a member of a nation's staff, but I plan on working my way to that. (I'm currently reinstalling this game, and the game's done-- for now, this is my review, but I will add more later!)

content:
, 2015
												Ahhh, this game...  This game is definately worth sinking some hours into, especially if you're into Tactical RPG's, MMO's, or even managing a Nation!I first found out about Wakfu by watching the series on Netflix.  I thought "Oh boy, i wonder if there's a game for this!"  Turns out my ignorant self was unaware of the series being based off of a game!Finding out as much as I could, I was extremely pleased to find this game on Steam, and absolutely FREE, too!Anyways, back to the game itself, I've spent a good 130 hours on it now and I am STILL exploring the world that there is to see!  After a while you get tired of playing by yourself (if you're a social introvert like me) and you want to expand a little.  That's where making/joining a guild comes in handy.  You can find plenty of people to kill and gather resources with.The system incorporated into the game are kinda... well, up and down.  The currency system, as well as the ecosystem and government, is all player-run.  So you'll have to checkup daily for new prices on an item you want.  And the crafting system is a little over-the-top.  Why do I need almost 32 bits of wool to make clothes!?All in all, it's a good time-killer if you need an excuse from the world and want something a little different than MMO's like World of Warcraft.I give it a 8/10.

content:
2015
												I love the game. Really do. It has the old isometric feel of old rpgs, and maintains the turn based combat with grace, hardly any part of the combat system feels clunky or out of place. Even grinding for xp (Trust me, you'll have to do that A LOT), there is a sense of achievement in beating your foe. The artstyle is really good, on par with the French TV show about it. It also has a nice diversity of classes, weapons, and fighting styles, for a free to play game. Also, DUNGEONS! There's a fantastic diversity of dungeons that help you level up, get some kick ♥♥♥ items, and are evidently made with a lot of thought and care.Now the bad parts:It's often a bit laggy, not enough to make you sick, but enough to annoy you after several hours of viewing it. The game as mentioned before, is incredibly grindy. They give you a few missions to get you on your feet, and then set you free. to some, that sounds like a gift, but trust me, it's a curse. Yuo get lost easily, and the map is no damn help at all, so you end up killing Bow Meows (cats) until you stumble on an adventure. They have a lot of items and dungeons that can be only unlocked by being a certain level, which is to stop new players from being stomped, but leveling up becomes so hard after level 10 that you end up forgetting about dungeons, which is a shame because they are SO FUN. Customization, one of my most important parts of an rpg, is pretty much nonexistent, so make sure to create your charater EXACTLY AS YOU WANT THEM TO LOOK LIKE becaue there is no covering your mistakes in heavy armor.Other than that, the game is a really good time waster. Even though it gets very dull quickly, I find that I keep coming back to it, and I've made it a bit of my daily habit. Would recommend at the very least, try it. If you don't like it, the uninstall button exists for a reason.

0, 2015
												This game is pure genius.  The battle style is similar to Fire Emblem, but you can actually play with other people in real time.  Only annoyance might be waiting for them to complete their turn.  The game is colorful, bright, and welcoming.  Plenty of "classes" to choose, all which have a male/female version of them (even Robots).  Level up and do dungeons with your friends to gain equipment, stats, skills, items, and keys to more dungeons.The game even features some other skills such as mining, farming, and crafting.  There seems to be always something to do.  The game even has competing nations, PVP, and guilds.The only gripe I have with the game is that it's primarily sandboxed; in the beginning you'll have plenty of quests to get you going, but at some point the quests do stop, which leaves it up to you how you want to play the game.  Do you want to grind to the highest level?  Do you want to help newer people grind to the highest level?  Do you want to take it easy and become a farmer for the rest of your life? The choice is yours.  However, when I got boosted to a higher level, I had no idea what to do because of the limited amount of quests.

Let's keep our hopes up that the lacks I mentioned before won't bother us for too long.

content:
, 2015
												Wakfu is a fun and adventurous game. It has turn based battle style fighting, a huge and expanding open world, interesting mob monsters (little birds called tofus- if you're vegitarian you won't want these Tofurkeys, Bow Meows, Treechnids, lots of weird stuff). Its a player run game, with 5 different governments that players can be elected into. Bonta, Amanka, Brackmar, and Sufokia cough cough Sufokia being the best, of course cough cough are the four land owning governments. The fifth is a group called the Riktus Clan who are sort of a pirate/rogue group who go around and wreck shop and steal land. You join one of the land owning countries at level 18 or so, and later get the option to join Riktus, if you're so inclined, aroud level 35.The best way to level up is to scour the many dungeons scattered across each country, and the neutral lands (ex Astrub, The Sadida Kingdom, and other such islands found on the map). Getting into the dungeon itself provides a challenge as you have to fight area monsters to get keys or ingredients to make keys to get in. Each player requires a key to get in. Groups are suggested for dungeons, though you can use a 'sidekick' which is basically a second character you control. Sidekicks require you to use a key as well, as they count as a second person linked to yourself. At the end of a dungeon you earn experience, items and tokens which allow you to buy other items from a machine outside said dungeon. Those items from the machine are linked to your player character. You can also run the dingeon multiple times to get all the items from a set without them being linked (most times).Then there are things that I consider 'sub classes' that help you make pretty much anything in the game. These jobs allow you to make armor, weapons, furniture for your havenbag/home, accessories, food, etc. They are on their own leveling system unrelated to your characters level. The CRAFTING professions are: A.O.E Weapons Master, Armorer, Baker, Chef, Close Combat Weapons Master, Handyman, Kama Minter, Leather Dealer, Long Distance Weapons Master, Jeweler, and Tailor at the time of this review. There are also GATHERING Professions, which help you get the ingredients for crafting. GATHERING Professions are: Lumberjack, Herbalist, Miner, Fisherman, Trapper, and Farmer. These professions also offer unique items to craft, though are best leveled up by actually gathering things.This game is very time consuming. But fun as all get out.In this game there are a lot of guilds. When I say a lot I mean, like, over 500. Many may be in disuse or inactive, but there are a lot of options out there. Look into the guilds and join one that makes you comfortable, you can always make one of your own if you want to. Guilds provide boosts you can't earn without being part of a guild. Stuff like increased HP or damage for a certain element, depending on the guild level and amount of points they've earned. Guilds have 3 daily quests that grant 15-20 points per quest per character that does them. You also earn small amounts of guild points just doing whatever if you're grouped up with members from your guild- like the little environmental quests (like kick 10 Gobball Balls or stomp some weeds type things), running through more than one dungeon (though the one daily quest for that grants 20 each time after grants a few points too). You can always leave a guild as well, f it no longer suits your playstyle, though you will lose all related bonuses.On the topic of dailies; there is a temple called the temple of almanax. It has 4 doors correlating to the seasons inside, and once a day you go to 'pray' to the merida of the day. It grants a token that allows you to buy cool stuff like costumes or a pet or haven bag upgrades, something like 10,000 exp, and a randomized bonus (something like +40 Wisdom or +30 HP and other things like that. the bonuses last one hour of gameplay).Theres so much in the game, it is really worth it to give it a few hours to try, it is free after all. Theres also a user-run wiki for Wakfu that covers a bunch of stuff and is always expanding (albeit slowly sometimes). Theres also Ankama's site that has more info on specifics as well.All in all, its worth a try at the very least. Its fun, its enjoyable, and its free (though you CAN choose to spend some real cash if you really want, but you don't have to)

												This is one of the best MMORPGs I've ever played. The textures may not look so good if you play games for what they look like, but they've got theyr beauty. One more thing: the game is MASSIVE, it has tons of areas to explore and a lot of dungeons, items, jobs, quests, anything... The bad stuff? Well, if you play alone it kinda gets boring, but it's a good thing that Wakfu has this amazing comunity, everyone is so friendly and helpful and stuff, no trolls, nor scammers, so you'll make friends real fast and you'll have for sure someone to play with. In the end: great game, also free so it won't hurt to try.

												A few key things to know about this game.1.) You will do a LOT of grinding.2.) The end game dungeon currently requires you to pay to even ACCESS. (No sub means the highest level area is locked out for you.3.) If you pay money you get to field more heroes/sidekicks allowing subs to monopolize more turns per fight4.) PvP is dominated by people who have sunk hundreds, if not thousands of hours into the game, even with subscriptions. If you plan on doing any serious pvp, it won't be until your AT LEAST 1,000 hours into the game. Until then be prepared for a lot of repetition. If one of these points don't turn you off then you might want to check the game out. Mechanically it isn't bad and the community, for the most part are a cool bunch of people. That said, around 120-140 prepare to spend hundreds of hours running the same 1-2 dungeons fighting the same group of mobs over and over again. Unless you can join a guild to find people who will help pass the repetitive nature of the game it will eventually get to you.NOT FOR LONE WOLF PLAY - PERIOD

												The game itself is very dull and slow paced. Tactical RPGs should never be MMO's to begin with and the game has very little driving aspect to get the players to play the game. That being said it still has unique features and fun gameplay mechanics that is better suited for single player. You can play single player in the game by building a bunch of characters and then sidekick them to your main character (with the only fatal flaw being you have to spend over 25$ just to even do that for 90 days). I like where Ankama is going with this but they are doing it the wrong way. They should do what Squaresoft did when they made Final Fantasy Tactics for the Playstation 1. If they were to do that and sell the game for roughly 20$ on steam than they would be able to have a successful video game. If people like tactical RPGs, this game will be up your alley. Just a note though: Game is kind of buggy and not many players to play with.

content:
ber 21, 2014
												Wakfu is a turned based MMORPG, that has interesting graphics, music, so on and so forth with things that've already been touched on. Lemme tell you about the part of it that really makes ME excited. Wakfu really tried to build a world that was entirely dependent on the people who play it. So, right off the bat? There are zero NPCs, aside from the occasional quest giver. That means if you're looking to sell your ♥♥♥♥, you better start up a stand. There's also an Ecology system that effects monsters and gathering nodes (trees, plants, ore, etc.) wherein, if you kill too much, or take too much, it'll actually GO AWAY. It's up to the player to repopulate these areas by planting things, breeding animals and generally working with the "Wakfu" of any particular area. Some other notable parts are as follow: Player elected governors, citizen points that can effect how the world treats you (Wanna be a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, be an outlaw and go to jail? Hell yeah you do.), instant player housing (Haven bag) that... also works as your store, a place to decorate things, a place to put gathering nodes and so on. There's also huge maps, the ability to spec into every kind of profession, interesting character classes that have little to no over lap as far as utility... I mean, come on!I'll admit I'm pretty stoked about this game. However, it is definitely not a game for everyone. The combat can be pretty off putting, and it's generally not as fun of an experience if you go at it alone. But, if you're the type of person that really likes to see a game take some amazing steps for MMOs, you might wanna give this a shot.

												The game itself is quirky, beautiful, and addictive. The classes are completely unique, and each has four different elements it can focus in, which makes for a lot of easy tailoring to play style.Even though it's the most aethetically pleasing MMO out there, it's still infested with middle schoolers learning their first swear words. It's an interesting sight to have some grouchy kid stomp the plants you're growing for a recipe while cussing you out, saying your flowers are too close to theirs. If you were expecting this game to have a nicer commmunity, boy, are you naive.Luckily, you can pick and choose which chat channels you see through buttons on the right of the chat box. You can have groups and guilds and the like, but I have become a hermit and still find the game fascinating.

content:
ber 23, 2014
												I played Dofus for years. I always said that Dofus is great game and you won't ever find game like Dofus. How wrong I was. Wakfu is like evolved Dofus. Sure it lacks some things we didn't even know we like in Dofus (e.g. you don't get all skills at once so you have more time to learn using them), but generally Wakfu is even better. Why is Wakfu so special? You have to use your brain while fighting. Of course you will have some skill pattern, few skills you will use again and again, however you have to know where to go, who should be killed first, etc. New monster means new type of battle. And another great thing Wakfu offers to its players is economy and ecosystem. There are no NPCs for buying/selling, everything is on players. Another thing, that depends on players is nature. You can gather plants, you can cut trees, but if you want them to grow again, you have to plant them. And monsters as well. Also everyone in certain area can get bonus, because special NPCs who take care of areas will tell you how much trees they want there, how much monsters, ... And if they are pleased, players get temporary bonus stats. I am not saying everyone will love the game, but I think everyone should at least try.

content:
ber 24, 2014
												If you like rpg's,mmo's or strategy games you will love this title. This game is soo good, while I haven't played too much Dofus, I am 18 hours into the game and I can say it might be as good as Dofus. + Hilarious dialogue and character names ( Also you can see animals make out )+ You are free to do whathever you like. Whenever you grind and feel like you are getting bored, there is a lot of things that will make the boredom go away, like doing dungeons,crafting,harvesting,exploring,pvp,guild wars and much more.+Quest's are always fresh and dont feel like your average MMO where you need to either collect this and this from an enemy or killing this and this number of enemies. Usually the only collecting thing would be harveting materials , and from killing monsters, its only optional because they will give you only a little bit more exp from eco quests or like i call them "field quests"+Beautiful art design , and just exploring through the scenery feels relaxing.+Great skills that have multiple uses,and skill resets if you are not comfterable with your char.+You can choose from a wide selection of  unique characters. Even the archer is so unique.+You can put items on sale while offline and you can fast travel + Ton of archivementsNow for the bad things-Game might get grindy at times-Discarding items is a pain in the something to do-You can't sell at merchants , instead you have to sell your items to players, or discard them.-You need to put a lot of time into it if you want to get to the fun stuff-You cant move with keys, mouse only. And no camera movement besides zoom in and zoom out.-Glitches. You have them.-WHEN CAN WE WATCH THE ENGLISH ANIME ?-With friends, this is a bit easy. (But still ton more fun)Final reviewIf you put time into it, its a amazingly unique game. If you wanna get through it fast, its gonna get boring really fast.7.5/10 Recommend it to anybody who loves things like fire emblem or final fantasy tactics.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 20, 2014
												Been playing this game all day and I only have a few gripes that are overwhelmingly outweighed by the positives.Cons: 1. Up until level 10 or so there are some really annoying quests but that's expected out of an MMO. There's one specifically which has you pushing flower pots into plants in some sort of puzzle that I find mind numbingly stupid. 2. The professions are an amazing part of the game but there is no mission or anything that really explains any of them. You have to track down the trainers themselves and read the little mini books the give you on each profession.3. The starter area is way overpopulated and makes grinding out some of the lower levels/gear grinding kind of annoying.That's the only real gripes I have, now, for the positives.Pros: 1. When they game says it has unique classes it really means it. I found myself making quite a few new characters just for the sake of trying out the classes. One that sticks out in my mind is the Escaflip which is a gambling class in a since. Certain skills in the class (namely the "Earth" path) are 100% based on pure luck. There are passives that make you luckier but I just find the class overall interesting.2. The amount of stuff to do fresh out of tutorial is amazing. Immediately what came to mind is runescape just on a smaller, better scaled version. Including the gathering, crafting, etc. which brings me to pro number 33. This one will vart from person to person depending on who you ask but I do not find the gathering to be tideous or boring, Wakfu is a beautifully designed game with vibrant colors and cute, anime like avatars. I found joy and going around collecting seeds from animals. Yes, I said seeds from animals. This sort of solves the issue with con number 3 because it takes roughly 5 seconds (no exaggeration) for an animal to spawn after you plant the seeds. 4. The community is very friendly and talkative. Now, me being a somewhat older player I found this to be annoying as well as helpful because, like I said, the game is very anime-esque. This means LOTS of 13 and 14 year olds. As long as you're the type of person who can easily ignore this it's no issue. If you go dungeoning that's where you'll find the informative, helpful, mature mmo players.I could go on and on about this game because I literally plaed it for about 8 hours straight. It's a fun game and I reccomend it to anyone who's looking for something new and different. solid 9/10

												Despite the amount of interesting open-world area, Final Fantasy Turn-by-turn gameplay style, it seems that it is just now mainly for Windows instead of the Mac, due to JAVA-Based compatibility. Especially from users that are new to Steam for Mac on Yosemite and Higher.The only fix is this is just only using a VERY OLD and maybe unupdated service to Java for Mac. Sooner or later, Java will kill off Java 6 (the game currently utilizes this version of Java) for all the new versions, so where does this leave this game?I think it maybe safe to say that the developers may soon need to think about bringing a major update to have new Java version support (Java 7 or 8 and newer in the years to come).

												The Show is wonderful and the game isn't all that bad but that being said it isn't all that good ether. It does little to hold your attention as I played it I found very little enjoyment in the combat system as I was thrown from boring quest to boring quest. What really hurts the game most though is how it trys introduce mingames viva the combat system one fine example is the Pizzalarva quest where the player is asked by a NPC to cook larva as this will train him somehow to fight Cult members. The idea was forced and the mingame itself was horrible as instead of just straight up fighting you had to not only keep the larva from reaching the end of the track but also had to tenderize and granish the larva the correct way. Sounds simple but in reality all the player finds themself doing is running back and forth from granish barrel to conveyor belt hoping that the next larva is the correct color and trying to keep other larva from escaping.

												honestly, this is pretty fun, it's a player driven ecosystem, meaning players who focus on different jobs, such as farmer, handyman, trapper etc. you also have a TON of classes to mess with, from the gambling ecaflips, to the situation changing masquaraiders, to the speedy portal summoners the eliotropes and a ton more, while you can have more then one job in the ecosystem, you will need help finding the items needed for some stuff, personally I recommend playing this game with a band of friends so you can all get a lot of stuff done and have a blast during the battles, which are freaking fun as hell, honestly, the only reason I would not recommend this game, is if your not a fan of grinding for stuff, or don't have a lot of time to spend, so for me, this game gets a solid, but not perfect, 8/10

content:
y 17, 2015
												PROS:Best ever game environment.  Beautiful art and style. Extensive crafting system. PVP option. Dungeons are unique and mob's are difficult to master-  they all have different abilities. Gameplay grind and difficulty creates a relatively mature player base. Can play for free if you can stand the grind punishment.CONS:Gear acquisition until you have a maxed out character is very punishing! If you're used to Warcraft dungeons, where you can get all the gear you need that matches your level running  dungeons, you're going to be frustrated. Dungeons AT YOUR LEVEL, are DIFFICULT for a group, YOUR LEVEL. So you're basically left with hoping you have some maxed level freinds to run you through, over and over. Which by that time, you've leveled past the gear you were after in the first place. The system really makes no sense.Getting groups at levels other than high levels is hard. Most players are maxed and have no incentive to help you with low level dungeons. They need to introduce player scaling and rewards so high level players are compelled to play low level dungeons.BIGGEST CON:  THE GRIND.It's the most punishing grind I've ever experienced- even if you purchase booster packs for 3x the XP. Now I only get to play an hour or two here and there and on weekends, but I've been playing about a year and my highest toon is 115 out of 165. People get around this by being "power leveled" by high level players- which is about as fun as teasing a cat with string... You're just there for idle chit chat while they blow mobs down- for hours....SUMMARY:One of my favorite games ever due to art, sounds, playstyle and difficulty. But it has serious flaws with helping and keeping new players interested (grind and grouping). Best summarized as an MMO Chess Game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
er 4, 2014
												Good:Combat is fun, especially with friendsThe world is very open allowing for exploration and training your skills well beyond your level (like mining and carpentry)All currency and item value is created and determined by the players, creating a unique market systemYou can wage war on other nations with more than just pvp, you can destroy their resources as wellBeing a bandit is actually helpful to other players, because they gain citizenship points for correcting your eco-terrorismBad:No one usually wages war. Most of the time everyone is friendsThere are no incentives to become a bandit other than for the hell of itGame suffers from imbalanced resources (using three logs to get one plank, and using 17 planks to make a box)experiencing minor, but consistent lag. Game seems to hickup ever couple minutes, or when pulling up the map/gathering resourcesSometimes creatures are labeled as “Busy” but aren’t doing anything, so you can’t get rid of them.Overall, a very good game and most issues I have with it can be solved if players start trying to kill eachother in-game.
